comments.commentBody: I wouldn't say this is the "worst deal ever," etc., but it does seem clear that the Knicks gave up too much for 'Melo, at least looking at it in terms of the next 1-2 years.  They are basically starting over, again, from scratch, to build a team full of solid complementary/role players to bolster the Amare-Melo-(perhaps)CPaul core.  Waiting for 'Melo to come to NY as a free agent would have been very risky, maybe impossible.  The Knicks had two realistic choices: (1) go the 2004 Pistons' route, let's say, with lots of solid, unselfish role players and old-fashioned teamwork (not how you build a dynasty, however: once they win a championship and become free agents, they all depart for the highest bidder); (2) go the Lakers/Celtics/Heat route, with 3 superstars (and all the media hype and egos that go with them) at the core of the team.  They (Dolan, Isaiah, whomever) chose option #2.  If they get CPaul, in a few seasons things could get very, very interesting; however, knowing the Knicks' recent history (well, the last 15-20 years) of trades and deals, etc., it may well go bust.  They need a legit center.  Even with A-M-CP (IF they get CP) as NY's "Big Three," they still don't have a real center.  As a long-suffering Knicks' fan, however, I would say this about this latest mega-deal: let's sit tight, give them some time to build a great team, and work toward bringing Chris Paul to NY.  And welcome home, 'Melo!

I thought we had rid ourselves of Isiah; but Dolan would rather listen to the person that helped run the franchise into the ground than the GM who put the franchise in a position to become relevant again. One step forward, two steps back...
Looks like the Knicks will be playing a lot of All-Star game type games with scores like 145-137 or so. Let's just hope that they end up with the 145!

For all of you who argue that "we could have gotten him in free agency," you are mistaken for two reasons.  Reason #1 - the current labor agreement expires after this season.  If the CBA wasn't being re-negotiated after this season, I would have agreed with you.  But Melo was afraid that changes to max salary deals, team salary caps, and the possibility of an NFL-style "franchise tag" would preclude him from getting the $ that he is getting in this deal.  Reason #2 - because Melo wants his $, he would not go to free agency.  Several reports stated that Melo would have agreed to sign with the Nets if trade talks with the Knicks failed.  Melo was not going into this offseason as a free agent, and risk losing $15-20 million dollars.  It was either the Knicks or the Nets.  I'm very happy that it was the Knicks.

Terrible deal for a glorified volume scorer who, if he really wanted to be Knick, could have signed here this summer.  That he instead insisted on getting his extension, while watching his new team's roster be utterly stripped of every remaining asset, says everything about his intelligence, character, and commitment to winning. And as for Dolan and Isiah, the less said, the better.  They truly deserve each other.  After 43 years, I'm done watching this team.

Wow - after watching December's Knicks-Celtics game (the one with Amar'e's last-instant 3, too late by less than half a second), I was looking forward to seeing some real competition from the Knicks.  Neither Anthony nor Billups is a slouch, but if I were a Knick fan I wouldn't like this trade.  Giving up a *team* team that was going to grow together over the next few years, for a "Big Three" that is way less powerful than the other Big Threes in this conference, is not the way to contend.

Hey Hank, maybe you concentrated a little too much on eating Ring Dings, and that's why you lost the job of running the Yankees to your little brother Hal. It's time for the second Steinbrenner on the Totem Pole to shut his mouth...

George behaved like a spoiled bully.

Why shouldn't his son?

Excuse me, but weren't the Steinbrenners the family that decided to make millionaires out of ballplayers for the first time? How can you complain about a guy's house when you're the person who gave him the money to build the house in the first place. Oh, and what did he have to do for you to get the money to build the house?

Play baseball. That's all. How mixed up is that? When a society compensates an entertainer for playing a child's game.

comments.userDisplayName: The Artist Formerly Known As Bakes
comments.userLocation: In the castle of my skin
comments.commentBody: What on Earth did I ever do to offend the fates... that I must be a Knicks fan?

Thank God they didn't retire #45 Tug McGraw's number.

Forget the numbers on the jerseys, play ball and win some games. That is what ALL the METS should be concerned about....... Let's go Mets!!!!

Here here, pmwarren and David Gustafson.

Hank's a chip off the old block. Everyone said George cared about winning more than anything else. Wrong -- George (like Hank) cared more about his ego and getting the credit for winning more than anything else. He thinks he's motivating Jeter but really this is Hank's way of saying "Last year wasn't my fault." I guess the buck stops somewhere else.

So why, Mr. Kepner, are you writing this story?  It's nonsense.  Just because Hanky-panky says something stupid doesn't mean that you have to write about it.  Don't you have anything more interesting, more compelling to write about?  Or are you just his publicity puppet?  Give us a break, please, and stop this foolishness.
Looks increasingly likely that George had one too many sons.
Put A-Rod in center and Jeter to third? Can you tell I'm not a Yankee fan?

Hey Hank, please shut up and let the Yankees move on through spring training and the regular season.  There are too many unnecessary distractions made by the media, let alone the management's mouthing off.  C'mon, let our guys focus on winning instead of defending themselves from ridiculous statements (aka yours!)  Go Yankees in 2011!

As Reggie Jackson said, the Yankees players weren't getting paid all that money to win 95 games in the season, they were paid to win 11 games in October.  Their hunger fell short by 6 games in October.
...did Prokhorov send ex-KGB guys to infiltrate the Knicks organization or something?
#3  At what level of square footage does it cease to become everybody's business?  I didn't realize there was some sort of rule about the size of one's house and public disclosure.

Denver called the Knick's bluff. Nets pushed the anti. Dolan (ooha) can never get it right. Good to have Anthony, but seemed the price could have been better if they played their cards right. I guess its back to the waiting game. Hope they can keep it together as a core duo until they can buy reinforcements... a couple of years.
As long as Dolan owns the Knicks they will never be a great team. Fans should sue for ownership.
Occasionally J. C. Tremblay of the Canadiens would lob a shot from his blue line that would bounce in front of the other goalie, handcuff him and go in...

Spector clearly has some skills, although playing fullback isn't among them. But the two goals that sent Man United to their first defeat of the season were not the only ones he's scored for the Hammers.
Even though he's still only 24, h's played so very much more than, say, Altidore has in the past couple of years. He's pretty much never going to impose himself into the USA midfield, no matter how hard he tries or how much progress he makes.
If Daniel above is right, and his strongest suit is indeed crossing the ball, maybe his future is as a wing, although he may not be pacy enough to intrigue the National team management. The front line for the USMNT is a bunch of cyphers and question marks. Spector should be asking himself, 'why not me?' Anybody who plays forward (sorry, Robbie Findley excluded) should be asking themselves the very same question.
And Patrick above is being awfully harsh on Spector. West Ham didn't drop into the cellar solely on Spector's work; it was an entire team effort. There is too much talent on that squad for them to be so terrible. Rob Green and Matthew Upson are still being picked by Don Fabio, so they certainly bear a lot of the load for this team's underachievement.

I don't know any faculty that works 30 hours a week and makes over $100,000+. Maybe at some big research university among the most senior and tenured but the fact of the matter is that most colleges and universities do not reflect that. I teach at a liberal-arts college- I came out of a # 1 humanities program, with degrees from a top liberal arts school, an Ivy and a major private non-Ivy and I make $50,000. Not bad-- I didn't get into this for the money--but consider that I have $60,000 in student loan debt and that I was in school for all of my 20s so I could become a college professor. (And I got lucky and actually got a job.)
I teach because I love the kids, I love the exchange of ideas, and I love my subject. I didn't get into it for the money-- but i went to school just as long as a medical doctor, longer than a lawyer, and I will never approach their income.
But that is okay to me, as long as I do what I love and get paid and treated fairly. But please, please, disabuse yourself of that misguided notion that faculty are rolling in the bucks. We aren't. I live in a small apartment- make payments on a modest car that gets me to and fro and certainly do not take European vacations or wear designer clothes. And I sure as hell don't work 30 hours- try 60-70 hour workweeks, with the actual teaching, office hours, grading, research, writing and all the other stuff I have to do combined.
My property taxes went up over a hundred a month since Christie took over.
